sn36.3:4.4: The tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The tendency to rigidity should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.
sn36.3:4.5: When a mendicant has given up these tendencies, they’re called a mendicant without tendencies, who sees rightly, has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”
sn36.3:5.3: the tendency to greed is there,
sn36.3:5.4: if you don’t see the escape.
sn36.3:6.3: the tendency to rigidity is there,
sn36.3:6.4: if you don’t see the escape.
sn36.3:7.1: As for that peaceful, neutral feeling:
sn36.3:7.2: he of vast wisdom has taught
sn36.3:7.4: you’re still not released from suffering.
sn36.3:8.1: But when a mendicant is keen,
sn36.3:9.2: they’re without defilements in this very life.
sn36.3:9.3: That knowledge-master is grounded in the teaching;
sn36.3:9.4: when their body breaks up, they can’t be reckoned.”
